section.heading: Argument of John L. Capell, III

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in 1119, Orr against Orr.
Mr. Capell, I think you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Chief Justice.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
William Orr has been required to pay alimony to his former wife under Alabama statutes, which require payment of alimony by husbands only.
And so the question before you today is whether or not these statutes violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of our United States Constitution.
This Court's precedent establishes that laws classifying on the basis of sex are unconstitutional when rooted in the role-typing, one should routinely imposed on women and men.
Two; when that notion that women are men's subordinates and three, over broad gross ranking of men as dominant and independent, women as weak, inferior and dependent.

As appellee puts it, the law derives from a view of the married woman as a non-entity, a view maintained for centuries but now recognized as archaic, outmoded, and wholly inconsistent with the equal status and dignity of all persons under our law.
Alabama's scheme rooted as it is in historic role-typing cannot be justified as remedial.
Any attempt to address the classification in a compensatory cloak is inevitably deceivable.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Would you say that there was something in the nature of role casting and stereotyping in Kahn against Shevin?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Kahn v. Shevin, sir is a - - I am going to in a moment.

In Kahn v. Shevin, they said was, your Court came out and said that it was alright in that instance because we were dealing with a tax situation and as pointed out in that case, the states are given great leeway in Kahn v. Shevin.
However under the Alabama statute, Your Honor, the situation is on a case-by-case method.
Read in context with Alabama's alimony statute is common law origin, the Alabama law was hardly designed with economic preference for women in mind as was Kahn.
On the contrary as the appellee's brief pointed out, the common law subordinated the wife to the husband.
It declared the wife disabled, stripped of her capacity to sustain herself.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, this particular provision of Alabama's law was certainly designed to prefer women, was it not?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: It was designed to prefer women sir because there is no statute which prefers men at all.
Men have to pay alimony for one reason because Alabama's statute says it does.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, now the real reason is that court ordered your client to pay alimony?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Based on an Alabama's statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes, but there wouldn't have been an order to the alimony unless the court under the circumstances of this case thought that such an order was appropriate.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: That is true if the statute would have held to be constitutional without the statute, so alimony could not even be questioned in the state of Alabama.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Did your client ask for alimony in the divorce proceedings?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: He would have had there been a statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Did he?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, no sir he did not Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And he didn't protest it?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He didn't protest this alimony?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: He was not allowed to Your Honor at that time because the statute did not allow him to even request alimony.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But he didn't?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, he didn't.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He didn't sign a piece of paper saying, now did he?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, he did not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Why -- the question on my mind and perhaps you can satisfy, that didn't seem to bother the Court of your state as why this is a case of controversy if your client didn't ask for alimony?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: The Appellate Courts of Alabama said if the appeal was timely filed when we questioned the judgments that were being -- trying to be obtained by the appellee wife against Mr. Orr.
At that point in time, he questioned whether or not this would be a valid judgment based because of the constitutional issue which we are presenting before you today.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But your claim is that, as I understand it that this law of your state is unconstitutional because it authorizes a court to award alimony only to a wife at the expense of a husband?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: That's right sir, that is – it's only gender line strictly on sex --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right and but such there could be a law, preferably constitutional law in your submission that authorized a court to order alimony to either party in a divorce.
In any event this case, the court ordered your client to pay alimony.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: That is correct, the lower court ordered --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I don't see how this controversy arises unless or until there should be a case in which the divorcing husband asks for alimony from the wife and the court of your state said, no I'd like to give it, it should be given in this case, but I can't under the statute.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Alright Your Honor, let me see if I --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Nor does your case as approaching that --

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Well, let's look at it this way Your Honor.

When a man comes into a court in Alabama in a divorce suit, the Statue of Justice is speaking at that point in time Your Honor to determine what sex he is and they are tilted with the point in time when that man walks into court.
Consequently his ability to --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Generally the husband is of the male sex.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, and consequently also Your Honor the scales are tilted in favor of the woman immediately.
He is bargaining power is suddenly gone from the very point he walks in.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, let's accept that, but in this case, in this particular case, what is that, that your client was deprived of?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: My client was deprived because of the alimony statute, was suffering financial burden based solely on the unconstitutional statute Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did he say to the Court, I want $500 a month because the statute which we have had here is an unconstitutional statute and you must give me the same treatment that you give to the wives?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: He did so in a subsequent hearing Your Honor, which is attached and made a part of the appendix of the record.
He raised it when she tried to come in and say, you have to pay me these many dollars and he said that judgment would be illegal because it was being based on a statute which is unconstitutional.
Had he had been in an alimony statute in Alabama, which was sex-neutral, where Mr. Orr could have come in and say, I want alimony, he would have done so.
Yes Justice Marchall?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there any payer of alimony in Alabama today who wouldn't have the same result if you win your case now?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Would you repeat the first part of that, I am sorry.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could every man who've been divorced and has paid alimony in Alabama today, would he have any readdress?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: He could file what was called a petition to modify Your Honor in Alabama based on the change of the law if this Court held the Alabama statute unconstitutional, but this would be hailed again Your Honor on a case-by-case basis.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And if this is a man who never litigated this point any place, and he just comes in and say, I want my money back.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, he litigated it Your Honor in the --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He never raised this point, you didn't.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: In the Court of Lee County, yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Your case said that anybody who had not litigated this point can come in on a contemporaries and win, isn't it what your case is?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, not exactly Your Honor.
It was raised at this proceeding.
It was raised in a contempt preceding this issue all of the Alabama alimony statute and it was raised for the first time at that particular point sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: May I ask you another question relating to your pros pose (ph) standing here.
Your client agreed to pay this alimony.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes my client, he signed an agreement which the court of Alabama says by its law sir, that it goes into be sure that the woman, not the man but that the woman is protected to sustain the case in Alabama.

Mr. Orr had he had the opportunity though of a sex-neutral statute Your Honor at that time he walked into Court, when he walked in the first time, it is our position he would not have signed an agreement, but he did sign it because he is more vulnerable because of his sex.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Did you make any record at that time as to what he would have done had it not been for the statute?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: It was raised in the first time that my representation of Mr. Orr Your Honor, which was at a contempt proceeding before the Circuit Court.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: At the time he signed the agreement, he made no reservation whatever?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: And I ask you now, why isn't he bound by his agreement?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Because of the wordings of our statute, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: The agreement does not say, I hereby agree to pay alimony to my wife only because the statute of Alabama does not allow alimony to be paid to the husband; it is just a flatter agreement.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, but it is an agreement that is incorporated into a final decree which is looked at by the Court and the lower court at that point in time looks to see what Alabama pay should require that the woman is protected, nothing mentioned about the man.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Right, but he undoubtedly gained something or perceived that he was gaining something from entering into that agreement, normally one does not agree to something without some consideration flowing to him or her.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: In divorce proceedings Your Honor, in Alabama there are three parties to every agreement.
There is the man, there is the woman and there is the state of Alabama.
The state of Alabama as the cases have pointed out, is a silent party looking to see what, that the women are protected; this case was cited.

This is what Mr. Orr is contending that had he come in, had he been allowed to come in on a sex-neutral basis and he is ready willing and able to go back and to fight on a basis of sex-neutral battle which would be up to the Court of Alabama to hear.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Capell.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Rehnquist --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What are we to take it from the procedural history in the Appellate Courts in Alabama in this case?
I take it that the Court of Appeals, the intermediate Appellate Court did pass on the constitutional question which you raised and it ruled against you.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: That's the Court of Civil Appeals did Your Honor.
They did say that this issue that we were just discussing, while it's timely filed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Right, and then you petitioned the Supreme Court of Alabama for certiorari?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: That is correct, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And the majority of the Supreme Court of Alabama simply did not write an opinion, it simply held that the petition for a writ of certiorari was quashed as improvidently granted.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Now do we have any opinion of the highest Court of the State of Alabama as to the constitutionality of the statute?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, if you are following that statement of that being quashed, if you look at Justice Almon's statement, which is a concurring opinion with the majority, you will see that it states and I am quoting in essence that any statute which favors women against men is constitutional.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But I take it he concurred specially because the majority did not agree with it, that is what the experience we usually have here?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And the majority are simply silent and I am wondering in view of our long established rule that one must raise the constitutional issue at the very first point in any state proceeding and must renew it throughout that if Justice Powell's question to you does not suggest that perhaps the Supreme of Alabama thought the Alabama Appellate Court was wrong in passing on the constitutionality of the issue?
The if the result was right, but that it simply should not have opined on the constitutionality?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: I would like to respectfully state that opinion would not be the reason Your Honor, I would like to maintain before this Court that Mr. Orr does have a standing based on the facts of the Alabama statutes as we have specified.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I am not talking about standing Mr. Capell.

I am talking about whether or not the Supreme Court of Alabama, which is the highest Court of Alabama, in fact did give a judgment on a constitutional question which is properly now before this Court.
I realize the intermediate Appellate Court did.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir and I have no answer for you to that question Your Honor.
Read in context with this common law origin, the Alabama law was hardly designed with economic preference for women and men.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Excuse me Mr. --

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- Capell, I am sorry to interrupt up you again, but just so I understand.

My brother Rehnquist in his question referred to the order of the Supreme Court of Alabama, quashing the writ of certiorari as improvidently granted and then Judge Almon or Justice Almon says I concurred in affirming the Court of Civil Appeals.
Is the effect of quashing of a writ of certiorari as improvidently granted in your state, the same as affirming the Court of Appeal?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: In my opinion in this instant that issue, that answer is correct sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because of course that is quite alien to the tradition and practice and rule here in this Court.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: That is correct sir and I do not have a -- I would be happy to brief that point and submit a subsequent brief to you on that point Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Why doesn't the posture of the case the same as though they had denied review in the first instance?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, my question -- Justice Almon concurring in the quashing of the writ as improvidently granted says, I concur in affirming the Court of Civil Appeals, so does that mean that it was affirmed?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: It meant that the finding of the alimony statute of a constitutional by the Court of Appeals that they are affirming the statute of Alabama concerning to alimony statute sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, they are affirming a judgment of the Court to which the writ of certiorari is directed?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are they affirming it or they simply dismissing it or quashing it?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Well, quashing means dismissing.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And what is – you are a Alabama lawyer and you could presumably tell us about the practices in your state?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Right, quashing does mean to dismiss in my opinion, however --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Rather than affirm?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, but however, Justice Almon said and he had a concurring that he does affirm, he would affirm --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He says he concurs in affirming.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not that he would -- not that he individually would affirm?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: And I do not know Your Honor if that's slightly opined or what of that issue.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But he cannot bind the other members of the Court by any characterization that he puts on in a single opinion, can he?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, Your Honor.
Getting back to the question that was asked I was though, when read in context with this common law, Alabama law was hardly designated with economic preference for women.
On the contrary, as the appellee's brief points out, this common law subordinated women to husbands; declared wives disable and stripped over capacity to sustain herself.

In essence, appellee's argument that the very legal regime discriminates against a woman can be salvaged if that regime throws the woman a bone after placing her in the cage and this argument could not withstand actual reflection and reason analysis.
You asked me about Kahn; support for one-way alimony statutes, there is a scheme now maintained by rapidly dwindling number of states.

Now, this Court's decision in Kahn v. Shevin can be distinguished, subsequent decisions Wiesenfeld and Goldfarb, make it apparent that Kahn will not bear the weight that the appellee would place upon it.
As we know Kahn upheld a property tax exemption worth $15 annually, granted to voters but not to where it was.
A key factor in Kahn was the other impracticability of awarding the $15 dispensation on a case-by-case basis.
In the show of contrast an alimony in Alabama has never awarded categorically.
The individual case, one's ability to pay, the length of the marriage, the other person's need, all these and other factors, determine how much should be paid and for how longer period of time.
But given that fact that Alabama has chosen to make alimony awards on a case-by-case basis, there is no necessity whatsoever for classification by sex.

Tax classification, because of the impracticability of individualized adjudications is an area in which states have large leeway, but there is no warrant for such leeway in an area such as the one at bar where adjudication must be made again on a case-by-case basis.
Thus the administrative convenience, the prime consideration in Kahn is not tenable argument to our case before us.
Sparing the public purse is not a consideration here as it was in Kahn.
And in addition, the $15 favoring Kahn was no slide.
It was so slided, it could not be expected to affect the behavior of men and women.
However, a one way alimony statute is the large and capricious reminder in reinforcement of society's traditional type casting.
Yes, Justice Marshal.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Let's get back to the present day.
You said there was an opinion of Court of Appeals, I can't find it, it's just nowhere.
So, where is the opinion that declares this statute constitutional?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Alright sir.
You look at the Court appendix say -- look at page number 10-A if you will Your Honor, on the jurisdictional statement.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The Opinion by Judge Holmes, is that what you are --?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, that is it Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: This is the order of 15-A, that's the order on 15-A.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I see, thank you.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.
Putting Kahn in perspective with Wiesenfeld and Goldfarb clarify that the Court follows no knee-jerk rule.
Women litigants win, and men, males lose.
As we know both in Wiesenfeld and Goldfarb, men were the complainers.
Men in both cases, as in the instant case, gender type casting frozen in legislation was the target, which was successfully attacked.
In Califano v. Webster, this Court carefully distinguished historic knee-jerk, gender-based categorization no modern law passed in direct response to a wage in job placement, bias against women.

The Webster per curiam makes it clear that the Court will uphold a gender classification, alleged to be it compensatory only if the law in fact was enacted to check adverse discrimination women encounter and not out of prejudice about women's weakness, inferiority, and dependency.
Further such genuine compensation clarifications must match that remedial end.
Therefore the differential at bar surely does not fit the Webster, it rests on the traditional way of thinking about females.
It plainly was not enacted to remedy or to reduce hostility to women in the labor market.
In summation, the gender classification at issue is a means to allocate maintenance, responsibility post-divorce is patently unfair and does not relate substantially to the state objective.

Functional sex-neutral classification is the fair means readily available to request rights and obligations between spouses, because one way alimony is a historical hangover that discriminates against men and stigmatizes women, the decision below cannot survive reason review and consequently we respectfully request that the Alabama alimony statute beheld unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Capell, before you sit down --

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes Justice.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: -- is there any case that is inconsistent with your opponent's theory that discrimination against men is permissible if it's economic discrimination, that's the heart of their whole argument?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes, its own economics and I think we have to differentiate sir again between Khan with Goldfarb and Wiesenfeld.
Goldfarb and Wiesenfeld, the men did attack this statute that favored women and were successful before this Court.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, why can't one argue that both of those cases were discriminations – well, let's see, those discriminations against men or women as you view them?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Well, I view them as the discrimination against men.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, there is an argument that the female wage earner was the victim of the discrimination, because she got less for her Social Security Taxes.
If you view them that way, is there any case that's inconsistent with their theory?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No, if you cast the case of Orr in a standpoint of economic considerations only where you have a gender type role casting.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: So my answer would be determination of how you look at Goldfarb and how you look at Wiesenfeld.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Whether they are discrimination against men or women?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Mr. Chief Justice, yes sir, excuse me.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Can I ask a question, if you should prevail here what happens?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: It goes back to Alabama Your Honor.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And then what?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Alabama will look at this case on a sex-neutral basis, looking at need not sex, looking at the ability to pay; looking at understanding of where both men and women come into Court on an equal basis, where there is no tilt, where there is no favoritism because of sex and that --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: What if your Alabama Court says that the result of this litigation is that no alimony is permissible in --

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Two things would happen very quickly Your Honor.

Again it's up to the Alabama and not this Court it's my feeling, but Alabama under the common law of doctrine that was in existence prior to the statute could take effect, but they would have to look at it with your order and mine, that is sex-neutral, equality under the law regardless of sex.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: So that even if you prevail here, you still may ultimately lose depending on --

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, depending on what we call losing and what we call winning Your Honor because I feel that when Mr. Orr came into the lower Court, he came in with not a chance to bargain, to place himself on an equal footing when this is over.
We ask for that right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You are suggesting that in every divorce in Alabama, the husband is ordered to pay alimony?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, quietly the contrary Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That's what I thought.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: And yet in many, many cases, there are.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are you suggesting that your client was entitled had the Alabama statute authorized and allowed it that your client was entitled alimony in this case?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Whether he was entitled to it or not, we wanted the right to ask Your Honor so that we could go in and quote for the right to obtain.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You certainly have said we don't under the circumstances of this case my client shouldn't pay alimony at all.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You just told me that.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And you said that.
Legions of cases in Alabama, divorce cases the husband is not ordered to pay alimony, right?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: That's correct sir.
But it is not based on – it was based on the need --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The circumstances of that particular case?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, and there are many men that who fit under that category who should be receiving and who are not sir, because of their sex.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, is your client one of them?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: My client would have asked and as a result of asking in my opinion.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But why, he didn't even say, he didn't owe any alimony himself?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Because --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Let alone ask for any from his wife?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Right because he weren't allowed to by Alabama law Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, you are certainly permitted as you just told me to say you didn't under the circumstances of this case owe the divorced wife any alimony at all, but you didn't do that.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, I did not do that because of the fact that is the matter that the state should take up again on a sex-neutral basis Your Honor, not on the basis of whether Mr. Orr is a man?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Whatever sex-neutral or whatever, you never took the position that you did not owe alimony under the circumstances of this case until this constitutional attack on the statute itself.
Under the circumstances of this case you never took the position that there should be no alimony award against you?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, we did not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: As you tell me, it was wholly permissible in Alabama for you to do?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: It was wholly permissible in Alabama for us to raise the constitutional issue.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No, no.
The contempt citation drew out of a court decree not out of any statute, didn't it?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yeah, based on --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And this court decree was based upon the circumstances of this case in which the court founded under the circumstance of this case your client should pay his divorced wife alimony.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, relying on this state statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, relying on the circumstances of this case.
The state statute doesn't require alimony that it doesn't pay alimony in every case, does it?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Not in every case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: But it does, but it strictly related to man thing not women paying sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Wasn't the divorce Court relying on a settlement agreement here?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, it wherein the state is the third party.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: [Voice Overlap] as Mr. Justice Powell pointed out, the court didn't have to make any decision except to pass on the settlement agreement, did he?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: That's why and under the state statute Mr. Chief Justice, they being the third-party involved in each divorce suit, don't look to the fairness of the award as they should which is our contention.
They look to see if the wife is protected; I am relying on the standard case which is applied to the attached --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, there are several others who were driving at, -- trying to drive that; wasn't the time for him to raise any constitutional question at the negotiation stage in which he would refuse to agree to pay anything and then he might be ordered to pay it and then he would challenge the validity of that order on the grounds that you are now trying to raise here and that the way of constitutional question?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, you are right Your Honor and but in addition to that Mr. Orr as the Alabama Appellate Court stated timely filed his objection to the constitutionality of that statute.
At the time he raised the issue or when she brought him into Court in Alabama --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the (Inaudible) proceed.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But under the existing Alabama law, you have told me that a divorcing husband is entirely free to make the point that he doesn't -- he shouldn't be ordered to pay his wife anything by way of alimony and you never even went that far.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: There would be no hearing on that Your Honor because the courts are not allowed to even decide that or to sit on it, they have even reversed a lower court which allowed a man to stay in the home which state in joint tenancy.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But that is.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Because of the fact that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How many Alabama divorces do you would suppose there are where there is no alimony award at all?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Probably, no alimony of any form --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Can't put a percentage on it?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, I would say Your Honor respectfully request to say to you that probably 25% of all Alabama cases there is not some form of alimony, be it alimony in gross.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But there is not any --

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: [Voice Overlap]

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- and that's perfectly permissible under Alabama law?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir, looking at the ability of the man to pay.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right and the need of the woman, including her age and the circumstances of the misconduct alleged and so on.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: We all know that but you didn't even take that position, let alone that you are entitled to alimony from the wife?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir.
This issue was not raised at the lower Court proceeding, the record is moved on that point.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, Mr. Capell, yeah suppose the Court of Appeals in responding to your claim had ruled that is as it did on the constitute -- but then said even if you are wrong on this nevertheless the statute would still -- we would still interrupt the statute is requiring alimony based on need as to either person and in this case, it is already been determined in the divorce court in effect that the wife was needy and that the husband could pay it and the husband doesn't challenge that here so we are just not going to change the, we are just going to rule against him here.
Suppose the Court of Appeals expressly said that.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: They would have been saying --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Would you be here then?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Would I be here, yes sir, I would be here for the sole purpose --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why would you?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: As in Dale v. Dale, in the Maine case, the situation is such that Mr. Orr standing to come into Court at initial time to ask for fairness and equality under the law the guarantees the Fourteenth Amendment.
These were not allowed to him but in addition.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let me ask you this.
Suppose as an alimony order, denying or granting alimony to the wife ever been reversed by an Alabama Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Only upon where the Judge abuses his discretion.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Suppose the husband is ordered to pay alimony and he appeals, has he ever won?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Has he ever won?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Has he ever won in an Alabama Court?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Sure, on the discretionary abuse by the lower Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: On whatever ground, on whatever ground, but so that the Alabama Court of Appeals if it had expressly said that there is already outstanding a Court order for the payment of alimony and it has never been challenged.
You did not challenge after that point except on the constitutional basis.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: We established it strictly on the constitutional basis, yes sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Capell, if you prevail and the Court should hold that the Alabama Statute is invalid.
Would that result in every alimony decree in Alabama being voided?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Because Alabama takes each case sir on a case-by-case.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: But the statute under which the decree was issued is held to be unconstitutional in this case, why wouldn't every one of those cases be analogous to your case?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: They would be, they would give rise to the case being brought back before if the man wanted to make the claim saying that this alimony based in max on my case was unconstitutional like wise, but the court would have a sex-neutral statute which I would hope this Court would look at it and adhere by and therefore they could go and listen, otherwise it would not automatically terminate each and every award of alimony prior to the case of Orr v. Orr.
Yes, Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Of all of the alimony cases that were handed down the same day this when was handed down, could they all file?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: I can't, Your Honor sir, I can't?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: I can't answer that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why could.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: I will say they could file probably.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If you could, they could.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And no magic, did you?

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: No sir, there sure is not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: john_l_capell_iii
turn.label: Mr. John L. Capell, III
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Capell.
Mr. Horsley?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You might tell us some early points whether you think there is a case here at all?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: No Your Honor, I do not understand the questions by the Court to Mr. Capell to be -- if he did not ask for alimony himself, that is Mr. Orr, why would he be able to challenge the constitutionality of a law which doesn't give him a right to ask for alimony.
I would agree that he should not have such a right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You don't make that point in your brief at all?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: No sir, I do not, I have not argue that point up to --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And he doesn't need to deny the wife's need?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: No sir, he does not.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Horsley, let me test that proposition.

Supposing instead of discriminating between men and women the statute said that in appropriate case alimony may be awarded against a black person, but no alimony might be awarded against a white person and then there was a divorce between two blacks and one of them subsequently sought to challenge the constitutionality of the statute even though that person had not affirmed that we sought alimony, he just been required to pay alimony, if you say that black person had standing to attack the statute or not.

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: Excuse me Your Honor, the statute said that the black.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Alimony may be awarded against blacks only.

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: Oh.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And the alimony was awarded against the black who did not ask for alimony against the other person in the lawsuit would the black person of standing to attack the constitutionality of the statute?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: I don't suppose that the standing question would be any different from this case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I don't think it would either and what's your answer?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: I am sorry I am not certain that I exactly understand the question.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The question is if instead of a discrimination between men and women it's where discrimination between blacks and whites.

Statute said alimony judgments may be entered against blacks, but not against whites and such a judgment was entered against the black person and the black person did not ask for alimony from the other spouse, but sought to challenge the constitutionality of the statute on the ground that violated the Equal Protection Clause.
Would the black person have standing to make the challenge?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: That's what I am saying, no sir I don't think that he would any more than Mr. Orr has standing.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right, because and why not.

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: Because he hasn't lost anything by it since he wasn't asking for alimony.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I see.

The fact that's the statute that gives the Judge the right to impose and to enter a certain kind of judgment against one class of persons against another no other does not give a member that class standing to attack that statute?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: It is my understanding that to raise the constitutional issue, you should have suffered the discrimination that you are claiming is inherent in the statute and if you haven't suffered the discrimination, then it is not up to you to raise the constitutional question.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: How else could once suffer the discrimination by being ordered to do what the statute authorizes as against just the members of that class?
How else could he suffer the discrimination?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: Well.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The burden has been imposed upon him that's authorized only against members of the class of which he is a member?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: Mr. Orr would have suffered discrimination if he had requested alimony and then denied it because he is saying the imperfection in the statute is that it doesn't give him a right to ask for alimony, but since he has asked for none, he has lost nothing.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: As I understand this Court's decisions since 1971 in cases involving gender classification statutes, it is the law that statutes granting an economic preference to women are constitutional and this is so because the Court had recognized that in this country there has been a long history of economic discrimination against women and statutes designed to compensate for that discrimination deny or violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Constitution.
The Alabama law undeniably, economically prefers women, but this preferential treatment as constitutional we say because of its compensatory function.

Mr. Orr, the appellant takes the position that the Alabama alimony law is based an archaic notion that women are not fit to be self-supporting and he says the law thereby produces dependency of women.

We say that it is precisely because of this archaic notion that women are unfit to be self-supporting that the Alabama law was necessary and we say that the Alabama law does not promote dependency rather at the time of divorce, dependency is already an established fact because of the discriminations that have been practiced against the women in the years leading up to the divorce.
The alimony law in Alabama far from promoting dependency gives the women some financial aid to help her overcome dependency.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What is there in this regular suit, Mrs. Lillian Orr is dependent on anybody?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: The judgment of the lower Court, the Circuit Court of Lee County Alabama.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Says that, says that she is dependent?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: I think that's the inference of the trial.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, I ask where did it say it?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: It is not written down so far as I know.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It's not in this record.

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But how can you argue it?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: Under the Alabama alimony law, in the cases in Alabama construing it, the trial judge takes in, is to take in --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That would apply to a woman who has an independent income of $80 million, right?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: What I am saying --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Right, right?

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: Would it apply to?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yeah.

Let me give an example of what I considered to be a fairly typical alimony case which I think illustrates the justice of the Alabama law.

If you assume that back in 1958, two persons 20 years of age of equal ability and intellect and competence were married, the wife at that point could well have surveyed the job market and made a decision to enter it.
You will understand we are talking about 1958 and this would be before the Equal Pay Act and before Title VII of the Civil Rights Act.
She would see a job market where she would make less wages than her male counterpart.
She would have less opportunity for advancement and perhaps even less opportunity to get employment.
So this hypothetical person back in 1958 would have decided quite reasonably to become a homemaker and the husband at that point perhaps went to work for a bank.
20 years later they both 40 years old, they are getting a divorce.
The husband at this point is inline to become President of the bank.
The wife, if she goes to work for a bank probably has to go to work as a secretary or a teller.

The difference in the financial rewards offered by the positions of bank President versus bank secretary are obvious, but the differences do not exist because the man is more competent than the woman.

The difference exists because of the discriminations against the woman that steered her into her role as homemaker and cost her to forgo the education and the training and the experience that would have today qualified her for the better job in the better paying position in the more responsible position.
Under these circumstances, we say under Alabama law it's entirely proper to compensate her to make up for the opportunity that she lost because of the discrimination she faced back at that time.
Now the appellant has made the point that there are some men who are dependent on their wives and they need alimony in the event of a divorce.

That's true and to illustrate that factual situation, let me reverse my example and suppose that this woman back in 1958 had in spite of the discrimination she saw in the job market, gone ahead and gone to work for the bank and the husband became a homemaker.

If they were divorced today it would be the husband who had the greater financial need than the wife, but under Alabama law he would not be entitled to alimony, but the big difference here is that he would find himself in financial need by choice rather than force.
When he surveyed the job market back in 1958, he did not find it unreceptive to him as it was unreceptive to his wife.
If he stayed out of the labor force it was not because of any discriminations against him and he would not have any claims under a statute which is designed to compensate for past discrimination.

I think this very point was noted in one of the dissents in Kahn versus Shevin where it was said while doubtless some widowers are in financial need, no one suggests that such need results from sex discrimination as in the case of widows.
I think that the same thing could be said of divorcee as was the set of widows.

Many states do have laws which provide for alimony to man and there is nothing wrong with such laws if that type of law is worth the legislature that state determines represents the will of its people but this is not to say that the legislation must be designed in that fashioned to be constitutional.
This is a decision for the state legislatures to make and Alabama has determined that its compensatory alimony law thus represent the will of its people.
So but for the archaic notions regarding women the opportunities would not have been denied them, an alimony wouldn't be necessary.
Since 1971, this Court has repeatedly acknowledged the fact that woman have been denied equal opportunities in the business world.
In the majority opinion in Kahn versus Shevin it was said there can be no dispute that the financial difficulties confronting the lone woman in Florida or any other state exceed those facing men.
In every sex discrimination case of this Court since 1971, it has been held that if the challenge statute granted an economic preference to woman, it is constitutional.
Dissenting in Kahn versus Shevin, Justices Brennan and Marshall argued that Florida tax exemption statute was over inclusive because need was not considered under the terms of that statute.
Under that statute, a wealthy woman who had not suffered from discrimination would have the same tax exemption that a poor woman would have.
But I am taking the position that the Alabama alimony law is not subject to that attack because alimony in Alabama is not mandatory.
It's up to the trial judge to make a determination as to whether or not it should be awarded.
Need is certainly a consideration to the used value judge in exercising his discretion.

In Califano versus Webster, this Court held that statutes economically preferring women constitutional unless one of two circumstances existed, unless the law has actually the effect of penalizing woman such as in the Wiesenfeld case or the law was not intended is compensation.

We have tried to demonstrate today that Alabama's law doesn't penalize woman because it doesn't produce dependency, it doesn't steer them into a role as a homemaker and make them dependent on their husbands.
As I have said I thank dependency is already established by the time of divorce.
The roles to be played by the parties to a marriage are ordinarily selected at the beginning of the marriage.
I don't think it's reasonable to suppose that marriages are begun in anticipation of divorce.
So the prospect of alimony should not be a significant factor in the selection of roles by the parties.
In any event alimony speculative is to where it will be awarded or not.
Mr. Capell mentioned that he thought perhaps in 25% of the cases there was no alimony award made.
I have no statistics to back me up.

turn.text: It had to be.

turn.speaker: w_f_horsley
turn.label: Mr. W. F. Horsley
turn.text: Yes sir.
In conclusion, Alabama's alimony law we contend passes the test devised by this Court in Kahn v. Shevin and Califano versus Webster.
Now on that basis, we would urge this Court to hold Alabama statute constitutional.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
